content:
mona Alr

Fadi AlNaji codeveloper of the UI COVID19 test showcases the plastic wells where saliva samples are submitted for analysis PERIOD

By Mona Alrazzaq Staff Writer January  

Julie Rodriguez sophomore in LAS enjoyed a bag of red hot Cheetos one early September morning prior to throwing on her mask oversized sweatshirt and white slippers to head to a COVID19 testing center on campus PERIOD After waiting in the short line it was her turn to spit into a plastic test tube PERIOD

As Rodriguez stood over the bright orange stickers labeled  feet apart she panicked at the abnormal sight of the pink saliva filling up her tube PERIOD She realized the pigment in her sample was due to the Cheeto dust in her junk food breakfast and then nervously scanned the testing center where every spot was filled to see if any eyes were on her PERIOD

I freaked out but I continued to fill the tube because I had no idea what else to do Rodriguez said PERIOD

Since nobody else taking the test was looking she attempted to nonchalantly place her pink sample amongst the others in the collection bin without mentioning the pigment PERIOD The person collecting samples noticed the color immediately and she was asked to throw out her sample PERIOD

Rodriguez is one of the thousands of students at the University of Illinois whose daily routines have been uprooted to include scheduling in a COVID19 test multiple times throughout the week PERIOD



About  of the total COVID19 tests conducted in the United States on a daily basis are conducted at the University of Illinois in UrbanaChampaign according to Illinois News Bureau findings in August PERIOD

Beginning an hour prior to the test individuals cant chew drink or even brush their teeth PERIOD Diana Ranoa a biology research fellow who helped with the formation of this test explained why this rule of no consumption during the time frame is especially important PERIOD

After people eat or drink there is an increased presence of enzymes in their saliva according to Ranoa PERIOD More enzymes could degrade the potential virus which leads to an increased chance of a false negative meaning that any food or drinks will have to wait until after the COVID19 test PERIOD

After waiting in a usually short line at one of the  different testing locations on campus individuals are asked for personal information before taking the test PERIOD They are then directed to a marked spot specifically placed six feet apart from other people around them also spitting in test tubes PERIOD

While staring down at these bright orange spots they are required to fill three fourths of the bottom of the test tube up with spit and place it in a large blue tray before they exit PERIOD

One tray of test tubes is a priority tray that is designated specifically for people who have been exposed to somebody with COVID19 have symptoms andor received an email in order to test three times weekly with priority standing PERIOD

Students living in a COVID19 hotspot or an area where many others around them have been testing positive receive an email to get tested more frequently with priority standing said Robin Kaler associate chancellor of public affairs PERIOD This way positive cases are caught sooner.Students who live in areas with extremely low COVID19 positivity rates are rewarded for their efforts to minimize the spread of the virus PERIOD

The majority of students are being so good with testing that we actually use it now to find the places that have the lowest rates and actually deliver cookies to them to say keep up the good work Kaler said PERIOD

Rodriguez is one of the students who is good with testing for COVID19 which is why she ended up taking another test at a different testing center an hour after her last testing incident PERIOD Before the second test she stood over her bathroom sink and spit in it to make sure that her saliva was no longer pink PERIOD

I knew I couldnt go back to CRCE because I was super embarrassed and the same people would be there but I still had to get tested Rodriguez said PERIOD

The saliva samples from each location are loaded onto trucks and transported to the Veterinary Diagnostics Laboratory at the University PERIOD There a team of around  technicians work in eight hour shifts in order to process the influx of samples according to Kaler PERIOD

Once Rodriguezs Cheetofree sample arrived in the veterinary diagnostic laboratory it was heated immediately for  minutes in order to inactivate the potential virus PERIOD Saliva buffers were then added to the sample in order to balance the pH level and sample additives are added to make the virus easier to detect PERIOD

The salivabased test developed by the University is unique in that it skips over an RNA extraction phase that traditional nasalbased COVID19 tests usually include and instead analyzes it with a RTqPCR reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction method PERIOD

This method makes the testing process quicker more efficient and less expensive compared to the usual nasal tests PERIOD Also the scientists who developed the test noted that people are more likely to prefer spitting in a tube three times a week with the saliva test instead of getting a stick inserted up their nose with the nasal swab PERIOD

Through the Universitys salivabased method extremely small wells in a plastic block are filled with different saliva samples and then the block is loaded into the realtime PCR machine for about an hour PERIOD

At the beginning of the tests development four scientists and technicians had to tediously fill each well manually by squeezing pipettes filled into the well and only had four PCR machines to do so PERIOD

Fadi Alnaji a virologist who helped develop the test noted that he is amazed at the automation of the test and how far it has technologically been able to progress PERIOD

I didnt expect at all that the development of this test would reach the level it has today seriously Alnaji said PERIOD

Ranoa explained how now scientists have streamlined the process in order to do batch processing by obtaining machines to assist in loading the wells as well six PCR machines in the lab that each process  samples per hour PERIOD This advancement drastically lessened the processing time of these samples PERIOD

While a sample is in the machine the DNA of the sample is generated from the RNA through a process called reverse transcription PERIOD Scientists can then add fragments that are specific compliments to that of the viral DNA to the sample PERIOD

Alnaji explained that they used the PCR kit because it includes three different regions of the virus and a control which makes it super accurate and reliable. these three different regions are the fragments that serve as marker labels to help determine whether or not the virus is present PERIOD

If coronavirus is present in the sample the DNA marker labels will connect to the viral DNA PERIOD This connection would release a colored lightup dye or fluorescent signal that is presented to a computer screen which scientists then analyze PERIOD

Samples with no virus will generally present a flat line to the screen meaning the sample is COVID19 free PERIOD Samples with coronavirus will lead to amplification of the viral DNA and the release of the fluorescent signal that will show up as curves on the screen in real time PERIOD

Dirt or air bubbles in the saliva sample could affect how the machine picks up fluorescent dye in the sample according to Ranoa PERIOD As a result the sample could produce a false background curve PERIOD

In order for a sample to be considered positive the curve has to cross a certain line which represents a threshold PERIOD This threshold is set higher in order to prevent false positives due to background curves PERIOD

Weve set that threshold at a certain level so we know at that line that all background curves will be under that line and be called a negative Ranoa said PERIOD All the real positive curves will be well above the threshold line and they will be called a positive. paul Hergenrother a chemistry professor at the University and one of the main developers of the test explained how one needs to be very precise about reading out the amplification plots and making sure the plots are the right shape for a true positive. hergenrother explained that scientists review the amplification plots of every result that comes back positive and make sure that they are consistent PERIOD This is to prevent a call for a false positive which could drastically change someones life according to Ranoa PERIOD

If youre positive you need to be isolated you need to quarantine yourself PERIOD We dont want to give a false positive call to a person and give them unnecessary stress Ranoa said PERIOD

After the data was processed in the lab Rodriguez was alerted on her online student health portal as well as an application on her phone designed by the University that her test results were available PERIOD Luckily the screen in the lab after her sample was processed presented a flatline and Rodriguez tested negative for COVID19 PERIOD

title: How sensitive is the UI COVID-19 test? Test developers explain - The Daily Illini
name: University of Illinois Urbana Champaign
